There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
transformed_texts:
My city is a melting pot, a vibrant tapestry of cultures and lifestyles. Residential pockets are woven throughout the urban fabric, tucked between bustling commercial areas that teem with a kaleidoscope of businesses. Offices stand shoulder-to-shoulder with diverse shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues, offering endless choices for every taste. 

The culinary scene is particularly exciting, with a plethora of new eateries constantly popping up, alongside well-established chains and independent boutiques.  These small shops, often tucked away on charming streets within walking distance of quiet neighborhoods, add a unique character to the urban landscape.  

Parks punctuate the cityscape, offering green escapes where families gather, children play, and a sense of community blossoms.  The diversity extends to the people who call this city home. My immediate neighborhood alone is a microcosm of the world, with a vibrant LGBTQ+ presence, a thriving Orthodox Jewish community, and families who have sought refuge and opportunity from the former Soviet Union. Venture a little further, and you'll discover "Korea Town," "China Town," "Little Armenia," and countless other cultural enclaves, each adding a unique flavor to the city's soul. 

However, navigating this urban expanse can be a challenge. Despite the abundance of attractions, the sheer size of the city discourages walking, leading to heavy traffic congestion, especially during rush hour.  A journey of just ten miles can easily stretch into a two-hour ordeal. 

Ironically, the city is experiencing a construction boom, with towering apartment buildings seemingly sprouting overnight. While this influx of new residents brings economic growth, many long-time residents worry about the strain on infrastructure and the loss of the city's unique character. 

Fortunately, the city offers a diverse range of housing options. Alongside towering apartment complexes, you'll find cozy single-family homes, duplexes, and smaller apartment buildings, catering to a variety of lifestyles.  

While our neighborhood isn't as tightly knit as it once was, there's a certain charm in its eclectic mix of residents and ages.  It's a city constantly in motion, a place where dreams are built and broken, where cultures collide and blend, and where the human experience unfolds in all its messy, beautiful complexity.

My neighborhood is a curious place. Most houses are single-family dwellings, yet a few have been split into two, still connected, if you can picture it. My house has a small patch of grass in front and a tiny driveway to the side. Like many others here, it whispers of a time when suburban life was the American dream. This dream once seemed to embrace the whole nation, but now it feels distant. Still, my neighborhood, like countless others, persists, calling out to us and visitors that the dream endures, held onto as best we can.

People aren't as optimistic as they used to be. Yards aren't kept up as meticulously, but there's still a car or two in every driveway, and children play with the world as their playground. The public school, almost 90 years old, still stands, conjuring futures in young minds while stirring nostalgia in the older crowd. Churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are always bustling.

Every house looks distinct yet carries a similar feeling. There's a large supermarket called "Super A," run by a Yemeni family, perhaps the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The majority of residents are African American. Wide streets are filled with children playing football, stopping only for cars to pass. Most neighbors have lived here for generations, sharing stories of a time when everyone knew everyone.

There used to be a karate school, but when Hollywood stopped churning out "Karate Kid" movies, the kids lost interest. Now it's a pharmacy, because, as I've heard, drugs fix everything. There's also a small movie theater showing classic films at bargain prices. It avoids the crowds because young people dislike its lack of new releases, but seniors appreciate the cheap night out, without the kids of course. 

There's a single expressway running through our town, with its entrance and exit in the next town over. There was once a petition to build an exit in our town. The youth supported it, but the elders opposed it, believing the expressway would ruin our town. They persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new high school, and we're debating on a mascot. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would perfectly represent our town.

At first glance, this place seems unassuming. Tucked behind a shopping strip in a residential area, it wouldn't be the first place you'd picture as a vibrant community.  You'd have to venture past the old, forgotten Whole Foods and behind the hotels, mostly empty except for occasional summer reunions, to discover a hidden world. 

There, nestled together like carefully disassembled Russian nesting dolls, are rows of apartment complexes. The first you encounter might have a bit of a shady past, so let's steer clear of those for now. Appearances can be deceiving, after all. But just beyond those, another world unfolds. One most locals never even know exists.

Opposite those complexes stands a quiet satellite campus of a community college. It's a haven of early morning coffee and sleepy faces, where students drift in at 7 a.m., yawning as they start their day. Iron gates creak open, admitting them one by one, while commuters grumble and shake their fists at the occasional traffic jam caused by higher attendance. 

The road curves, leading to another residential street with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for folks who've had some unfortunate mishaps. The center has a cheerful porch, a lazy ceiling fan churning the thick summer air, and a sense of calm. Children run and play in the park across the street, their laughter mixing with the buzz of bees in the flower patches.   

Retired folks walk their dogs, occasionally shooting disapproving glances at teenagers skateboarding and nodding at giggling girls gossiping by the playground equipment. There's a sushi place in a nearby strip mall, offering affordable meals, but never too busy. Next door is a swimming supply store, followed by a nail salon.  You could even get a manicure, fill your pool for the season, and grab some hibachi chicken, all in one stop - the epitome of strip mall convenience. A frozen yogurt shop with endless topping options adds to the scene, often filled with teens, their sugary treats in hand, performing skateboard stunts and vaping with an air of cool. 

This neighborhood is a true slice of Americana - a place where time seems to stand still in the peaceful south.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we drove past the endless cornfields that stretched out before us. I knew she'd be stunned by the vastness of the open landscape. She was from a town where the grocery store was just a short walk away; she'd never seen so much open space in her life.  Overwhelmed by the sea of corn, I shared stories of growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally understood who I was and where I came from.  Following a two-lane country road, we'd pass a quarry filled with water. Just past it lies the small development I call home. Most of the houses are built from brick and stucco, each sitting on at least half an acre of land that everyone takes pride in keeping immaculate.  Every spring, vibrant flowers bloom alongside the midwestern trees that change color with each passing season. The driveways are filled with gleaming, high-end Mercedes-Benz cars, sparkling in the midday sun after a good car wash.  Continuing down the road towards my own grey stucco house, we'd always see my Korean neighbor outside, a friendly face beaming at passersby. He spends his days tending to his lawn, his singing voice carried on the hum of his lawnmower. Everyone in the neighborhood finds his antics amusing, but he's a truly kind and unique individual with a fascinating past. As he's gotten older, his wit has faded a bit, but his spirit remains strong. He was a doctor once, now blending in with the grass and his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Finally, we'd reach my house. 
 In the side yard, geese waddle about, chased playfully by our terrier. Behind the house, a small stream flows into the quarry, where the sounds of bullfrogs, rushing water, and the occasional "moo" from nearby farms fill the air. Across a handmade wooden bridge lies a hidden oasis filled with native trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This was where I spent most of my childhood—building tree forts, "hunting" (mostly chasing) animals, and finding endless adventures with the neighborhood kids.  The winters in my small town can be incredibly harsh, but they're also breathtakingly beautiful. The yard transforms from a lush green to a barren landscape. The trees that once blossomed with vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers become skeletal remains of bark. When snow falls, a winter wonderland emerges overnight. Snow angels made by my little sister and snowmen line the backyard. My sister and I fought constantly as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapons of choice. We'd build massive igloo-like forts to store our "arsenal" of branches. In our own little frozen kingdom, we'd play pretend, escaping into a world where nothing else mattered—just two carefree kids, bundled up in winter clothes.

Portland, Oregon, is a city that proudly embraces its unique identity. It's a place where "weird" isn't just tolerated, it's celebrated.  You'll find this sentiment everywhere, even on a building that somehow manages to be a pizza place, bar, music venue, and even a strip club, all in one quirky space.  "Keep Portland Weird," the unofficial motto scrawled on its side, speaks to a deep-rooted appreciation for the city's unconventional spirit. 

For some, "weird" evokes nostalgia for a time when Portland was less well-known and more affordable, nurturing a vibrant scene of creative subcultures. For others, it's a welcoming invitation to join a community that embraces those who dare to be different.  

Despite the influx of wealthier residents from California and the ever-growing number of condominiums, Portland still holds onto its eccentric charm.  "Weird" doesn't mean blind acceptance, it means accepting things that often get overlooked elsewhere. It doesn't mean shunning modern comforts or avoiding the challenges facing the rest of the country; Portlanders buy their fair share of goods from China, just like everyone else.  

"Weird" in Portland is about finding diverse ways to express individuality, to embrace the unconventional. You'll find yoga studios, hipsters, and business professionals all coexisting peacefully. Perhaps, it's a matter of perspective - maybe Portlanders simply choose to take life a little less seriously.

In my neighborhood, as in many others, you'll find brightly painted houses, front gardens brimming with flowers, herbs, and vegetables, and a unique phenomenon known as "free boxes." These often-discarded cardboard boxes, or even plastic bags, are filled with unexpected treasures – clothes, books, and all sorts of other surprises.  

Walking through my neighborhood is like stepping into a treasure hunt, a testament to Portland's spirit of resourcefulness and community. This is just one small glimpse into the multifaceted nature of Portland's "weirdness." I'm just one piece of the puzzle, but I'm surrounded by thousands of other versions of weird. Some might scoff at the idea of rummaging through a free box, choosing instead to attend goat yoga or cheer on the local soccer team, the Timbers. Portland is a melting pot of passions and dreams.

Of course, Portland isn't without its challenges. Like many cities, it struggles with drug addiction and homelessness.  These issues are complex and deeply rooted in mental health struggles. The constant drizzle and overcast skies may contribute to the city's mood, and the influx of people seeking social services stretches the resources available. As with many cities, the non-homeless population grapples with compassion and frustration, a universal human experience. 

Despite these struggles, Portland's "weirdness" reminds us that it's okay to be different, to embrace our individuality, and to find beauty in the unexpected.

The mountains have always been a constant presence, standing tall to the north, witnessing the sun's journey every day. No matter how busy life gets, or how much I try to forget them, they remain steadfast, unmoved by the ups and downs of life. On days when stress and anxiety threaten to overwhelm me, they seem to beckon me, offering solace and strength. When I turn my gaze towards them, my troubled soul finds peace, and I'm reminded to keep going, one step at a time.  It was the mountains north of the campus that first captivated me when I first moved here for university. While the university itself has its own share of beauty, from its buildings to the ponds and trees, it's the mountains that hold a special place in my heart. 

The town itself is charming in its own right, with countless cafes that fueled countless late-night study sessions. A short walk or bus ride takes you to the downtown area, where faded brick buildings line the streets, whispering tales of a bygone era. Here, the town pulsates with a vibrant energy, rivaling its bustling urban neighbor. But just a few blocks away, the serene atmosphere of a small town returns, enveloping you in a sense of calm. 

This unique blend of urban energy and small-town tranquility creates a truly enchanting atmosphere, inviting exploration and discovery. Each corner of this town holds a memory, whether it's walking past the rusty swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or racing through the bustling downtown to catch a movie in the grand theater, courtesy of the university.  

But like all places, this town holds both joy and sorrow. The ponds, in particular, become a reflection of both, a place for quiet contemplation and tearful introspection at 2 am during existential crises—an experience I know all too well. Watching the turtles, ducks, and insects navigate their lives, each playing a part, I often find myself pondering my own purpose amidst the complexities of life.

One day, I found myself walking past the pond, the park, and the houses that epitomize suburban life, until I reached a main street. As the sun painted the sky with its golden hues, I realized I was walking north. There they were, the mountains, as steadfast as ever, their peaks piercing the hazy blue and yellow sky.  In that moment, their presence stirred within me a sense of resilience, a reminder that even amidst life's challenges, there is always something to hold onto.

Stepping into Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, you'll find it's easily accessible via the city's reliable public transportation system.  Being a quintessential New York City neighborhood, you'll feel right at home amidst the bustling energy.  

One thing that immediately stands out is the vibrant Asian community that has flourished here over the past two decades. You'll see Asian-owned businesses lining almost every block, with supermarkets and laundromats being particularly prevalent. These businesses are not just popular with the local Asian population but with residents of all backgrounds, thanks to their exceptional quality, competitive prices, and unbeatable convenience. Just a short walk from my location, you'll find a cluster of four Asian supermarkets, highlighting the accessibility of everyday essentials.  

While Bensonhurst is known for its strong Asian presence, it's also a melting pot of cultures, welcoming immigrants and their children who contribute to its diverse tapestry.  Besides the Asian-owned businesses, there's a recently renovated park nearby, boasting ten basketball courts, a spacious field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, a playground, and even a water fountain to keep kids refreshed during the summer.  True to New York City's spirit, the park reflects this diversity, providing a welcoming space for all. 

You won't find towering corporate buildings here. Instead, the neighborhood is characterized by cooperative living buildings, condominiums, and primarily two-family houses.  While the residents are generally friendly, be prepared for a bit of noise.  The constant hum of traffic, with cars blasting music and revving engines, can be a daily soundtrack.  

For those visiting at night, it's wise to be cautious.  While Bensonhurst is generally safe, like any urban area, there's always a possibility of encountering individuals looking to cause trouble or engage in petty crime.  I've personally experienced some unfortunate incidents in the past, such as being physically assaulted, but these were isolated events.  

Remember to keep an eye on your belongings, as package theft can occur.  One recurring issue is dog waste left unattended on sidewalks and streets, despite the city's regulations. 

Bottom line:  Bensonhurst offers a unique glimpse into New York City life, with its blend of cultures, bustling Asian community, and undeniable urban charm. Just be prepared for the noise and exercise a bit of caution, especially at night.

My neighborhood is perched atop a steep hill, a real "workout hill" for the joggers who frequent it.  There aren't any sidewalks, so everyone uses the road, which is a bit rough in places. The power lines strung across the area are a patchwork of repairs after years of storms bringing down branches and debris. Evergreen trees are everywhere, but they're not popular here. People want a clear view of the ocean, so they're constantly trying to cut them down. That's why many houses are built high up, boasting huge, glass-front second stories designed to capture the bay's beauty. Sunsets are magical, with the water shimmering and the sky ablaze with orange. However, it's mostly cloudy, so the sunlight often filters through a hazy veil.  Dampness is a constant companion, with moss clinging to everything - roofs, cars, even railings. I once left my car parked for a month and came back to a furry green coating! It took ages to scrub it off.

There are few children here, although a school is just a couple of blocks away. Mostly, it's older folks, many retired, who live in the neighborhood.  Dogs are the preferred companions, often seen lounging in yards or chasing each other down the street. They're bold enough to sneak into houses if a door or window is left open - I once found one napping in my living room! Rabbits are a common sight, much to the chagrin of gardeners who find their burrows and digging problematic. My cats, however, are delighted, having hunted most of them out of our yard. 

As for birds, we have the usual sparrows and hummingbirds, with the occasional hawk or eagle soaring through until the crows scare them off. There are no shops nearby, but a hike down to the waterfront offers a few seafood restaurants.  The beach is small, but the rocks along the shore are fun to throw into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide, so you can easily see the opposite shoreline, even through the mist.

Life in our little corner of Tennessee is pretty typical. We're nestled on a street connecting two main roads, so there's a bit more traffic than I'd prefer, but the neighborhood itself is peaceful. Folks tend to keep to themselves, tending to their yards and daily routines.  Winter brings the fun of sledding down the hill on our street, and living on the corner means we're practically the town square, seeing everyone come and go. We've gotten to know the usual cars and faces, so any newcomers definitely catch our eye.  Some neighbors are always out walking, either for exercise or with their furry companions. Kids whiz by on bikes, just like you'd expect in a close-knit community.  

We're a family of four, my wife, our daughters (eleven and fourteen), and me. Since we work from home, we're out and about quite a bit, so folks are used to seeing us around. Rain or shine, you'll find us playing in the yard. We love firing up the grill on our back deck, filling the air with the delicious scent of barbecue. The constant hum of lawnmowers from March to October is a soundtrack to our summers – there are a lot of green lawns to maintain! We're surrounded by trees, remnants of the wooded area this neighborhood used to be, which means a beautiful canopy of shade in the summer, but also a yearly leaf-raking and burning ritual come fall. The smell of burning leaves always marks the arrival of autumn. 

Lately, we haven't had much of a winter, so it feels like fall has dragged on forever. Our garage is at the back of the house, so we rarely use the front door unless someone stops by, which isn't often. When I'm working in the garage, with the doors open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays bring a bit more life to the streets, with families gathering and visitors filling the parking spots. Thanksgiving, Mother's Day, Christmas – they all bring a touch of extra cheer.  

Overall, I wouldn't trade this life for anything. The only thing missing is if it wasn't a through street – maybe some day.

Living in the heart of the high desert is a unique experience. It's a world of earth tones, with dirt stretching as far as the eye can see. Unless you've lived here, it's hard to grasp the constant presence of brown, and a vibrant lawn feels like a luxurious extravagance. Back in the 90s when I first moved here, houses were scattered, but now it's getting more crowded, feeling more like a city every day. It's a common trend, I guess. The people here are generally friendly, though like any place, there are good and bad sides. My neighborhood is filled with kind, older folks, which makes it feel quite pleasant. When it comes to shopping, it's mostly chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. For higher-end options, you have to venture further out. I don't see many Whole Foods or similar stores around.  

Construction seems to be the dominant industry here, probably because the city is still developing and there's plenty of open space. It's a little unsettling, to be honest. I left a big city behind, and I'm not eager to return to that kind of density. Speaking of construction, that's where I work—I'm a drywall and T-bar installer.

One of the things I love about this place is the wildlife. People are drawn to the high desert for its stark beauty, and the unique climate and landscape have created diverse ecosystems that need protection. It's important for us to learn about the animals that share this environment so we can coexist peacefully. My family has adapted well to the wildlife. My three kids are obsessed with lizards and desert bugs; right now, they're outside trying to catch some specimens.

We have a few local attractions, and Victorville is a great place for families to experience the desert in a unique way. If you're visiting, check out the annual San Bernardino County Fair—it's a blast!  Take a trip to nearby Wrightwood to see the snow-capped mountains and enjoy some winter sports.  If you're interested in the history and culture of the high desert, the Victor Valley Museum is a must-visit. It houses geological and paleontological exhibits, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville's development.

Describing my neighborhood might sound a little unusual compared to others. While most people here probably picture houses and lawns, my "neighborhood" is actually the college campus I live on. My dorm building is my home, and the students and staff around me form my community. The campus itself stretches out like a larger neighborhood, though not quite in the traditional sense.

Even with this difference, my campus shares some similarities with typical neighborhoods. There are "houses" – apartments, traditional houses, and dorm buildings –  just like in other areas.  The apartments, usually with 2-4 people per room and 4-6 rooms per floor, house around 20 people each. Then there are the houses, rented out mostly to alumni, that offer a more independent living experience.  And of course, there are the dorms, bustling with hundreds of students in shared rooms. 

My campus is a melting pot of cultures and ages.  Faculty and staff often live in the houses scattered around, while newer students settle into dorms and older students gravitate towards apartments.  

The campus also boasts a variety of stores, including dining options, clothing boutiques, and even grocery stores, providing everything we need within our "neighborhood" boundaries. Plus, there's a central park, a safe and welcoming space for everyone to enjoy.

Having lived here for a decade, I've gathered quite a few stories.  When I first moved from Riverdale to Stockbridge, I confess, my heart ached. Leaving behind my friends and loved ones in Riverdale brought tears to my eyes. But my parents, driven by the desire for a better life for me and my little sister, made the tough decision to relocate to a neighborhood with better housing, a stronger school system, and a reputation for being safe and prosperous.

Over the years, I adjusted and built a new life here. New friendships blossomed, and, yes, there were a few rivalries too. While I never truly connected deeply with most neighbors, I forged special bonds with Mr. Glen and his family, and for a while, with Dennis, who lived right next door. They became like family, and I cherish those relationships.

I vividly remember attending Mr. Glen's wedding (his second time tying the knot!). It was a joyous occasion, filled with laughter and dancing.  I even managed to catch the white strap he tossed - though I missed the bouquet!  It was a night of pure joy, and it filled me with a longing to one day create that same kind of happiness with my future wife.  I dream of building a life of luxury and showering her with love and care.

The neighborhood itself feels like a labyrinth, but now that I have a GPS, I'm eager to explore its hidden corners.  My adventures have mostly taken me to the places where I've hung out with my close friends Kason and Curtis. We were inseparable, spending countless hours immersed in the world of video games, chasing after the simple pleasures of youth.

Sometimes, I'd escape to the nearby park, finding solace in nature's embrace. The tranquility of the trees and the gentle rustling of leaves soothes my soul, bringing a sense of calm and peace.  I'd practice my balance with sticks I'd bought from Home Depot and even bring along my bokken wooden sword for some spirited practice.

The neighborhood also boasts basketball and tennis courts, though I haven't touched a racket or basketball in ages. Still, it's reassuring to know they're there, waiting for me should I ever feel the urge to pick up those old passions again.

You see, my dad instilled a love for tennis in me and my best friend with the help of Mr. Graves. We spent countless hours honing our skills, pushing each other to be our best. Those were golden days filled with laughter, sweat, and the thrill of competition.

Looking back, this neighborhood holds a treasure trove of memories, both big and small.  But these are the moments that have truly shaped my experience here. And as I look to the future, I can't help but feel that the best is yet to come.

My neighborhood is pretty close to my college, which is a big plus for me. It's mostly apartments, with a few decent, affordable restaurants and bars sprinkled in. One bar recently got a fancy makeover and jacked up the prices, but it's not terrible. Most of the people around here are either students or folks on a budget, like myself. There are a lot of kids because there's an elementary school nearby. I don't really know my neighbors –  I mean, we say hi sometimes – but I'm not looking to become best buds. They're big into weed, which is kinda funny because the building management put an air freshener thing right outside their door. Like, come on! The buildings around me are old-school but maybe have been updated inside. There are some brand new apartments down the street, but they're built cheaply and ridiculously overpriced because they're near campus. They can get away with it, though, because students will pay anything. There's a super cheap joint a few minutes away that serves everything on paper plates and mostly microwaves their food. Right next to that is a gas station, which I hear is a nightmare to work at.  Last summer, they redid the road with city money, so now there's a nice sidewalk, some grassy areas, and the whole area looks a bit nicer. My apartment building is tucked away under a bunch of trees, though they did chop down a few. There are more trees here than down the road a bit. Behind my building is another row of apartments, and then there's 43rd Street. It's not as charming. The sidewalks are cracked and falling apart, and the buildings look pretty rough. They've got a lot of trees there, probably to hide the buildings.  Most of the crime around here seems to be happening at an apartment complex on 43rd, but to be fair, the place across the street from me has its share of issues too. But overall, I like where I live. It's affordable, and I've got everything I need nearby.  Plus, it's a short walk to my classes, and there are bus stops close by to get to the store or downtown.

My neighborhood is a collection of duplexes arranged on a cul-de-sac, spaced out to resemble individual houses.  They all share the same distinctive look: sunny yellow paint, white porches, and green metal roofs. Most of the residents are friendly, often gathering at the end of driveways in the evenings to chat while their children play. It's a delightful break from the constant hum of modern technology, a step back in time.  

We're surrounded by fields and trees, bathed in the light of blue skies and fluffy white clouds.  However, this season has brought its share of challenges, especially with the recent tornado warnings. Last night, the sirens wailed, forcing us to seek shelter. I ended up in my bathtub, clutching my smallest dog, my purse, and a few pillows. My larger dog, unnerved by the commotion, stayed in the living room, barking anxiously.

The neighborhood was eerily quiet except for the drumming of large hail on the ground.  After the storm passed, the road seemed to steam from the sudden temperature drop, the hail melting instantly upon contact with the hot pavement. As the clouds parted, the sun emerged, and a double rainbow arched across the sky. I rushed inside to grab my camera, snapping pictures to share with my loved ones online. They were just as amazed as I was.

For an hour afterward, the streets remained deserted. Gradually, people returned home, and life resumed its familiar rhythm: children playing, mothers preparing dinner. It's a truly welcoming community for someone who recently moved here from New Hampshire. I adore the southern drawl, the warmth of the people. 

We all live in two-bedroom, two-bathroom apartments, though they vary in size on the inside. Some are quite small, which seems strange to me.  I love taking walks in the large field behind my home, strolling down to the pond (which isn't used for swimming). I've spotted deer, and in the mornings, a giant bullfrog serenades us with his booming croak. It's a wonderful place to live, just a short drive from Charlotte. Each day begins with the chorus of roosters crowing from nearby farms. It feels like living in a small village, complete with a friendly donkey at a nearby farm who brays in the evenings to let us know he's around. I feel incredibly fortunate to have found this hidden gem of a neighborhood.

Moving into this neighborhood right before eighth grade was a big change, and making friends took some time. But I ended up close with two guys, one just two houses down and the other on my street. They've both moved on, but the memories linger. Most of the folks who were here when I first arrived are still around, making this neighborhood feel familiar. It's pretty typical for the American suburbs, with lots of two-story homes. Weekends, especially when the weather's nice, are filled with the sound of kids playing outside. It's usually pretty peaceful during the week. I've never had any issues with anyone here. You get left to your own devices unless you need something, which is nice. I've ordered plenty of things online and never had a package go missing from my porch, so I trust my neighbors. There's a park just a short walk away, full of memories. We played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other neighborhood kids. I even got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good times definitely outweigh the bad ones. Now, whenever I go, it's to hang out with my cousins' kids. They're much younger and still love the swings and slides, but seeing them there brings back a rush of nostalgia. This neighborhood park holds a special place in my heart.   Things are pretty diverse around here, with a wide variety of food options. You can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants all within a mile radius.  These days, though, it seems like everyone's ordering takeout through apps like GrubHub and DoorDash. Fast food is popular, as you'd expect in any suburb, and there are plenty of pizza places too. The stores here have everything you need, from multiple dry cleaners to a Walgreens and a CVS right on the same street, plus a Jewel-Osco grocery store, a local favorite. There's even an Indian-owned store if you're craving homemade or ready-made Indian meals. Overall, I'm really happy with my neighborhood. Hearing the stories people share online or on the news about their neighborhood troubles makes me appreciate my own so much more.

Johnston, South Carolina, is a charming little town, a typical South Carolina town nestled amongst rolling farmlands. It's not flashy, but it plays a vital role in the state's agriculture.  The town proudly proclaims itself the "Peach Capital of the World," a title reflected in the vast peach orchards and cattle pastures that blanket the landscape.  

Homes are spread out, often perched on two-story foundations with sturdy metal roofs or gray shingles, ready to withstand the intense summer heat. They sit back from the road, leaving ample space for livestock and crops. The heart of town is defined by a lone stoplight at a four-way intersection, where a handful of businesses cluster. 

For a quick bite, you have a choice of Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's Burger Joint. Sadly, the town's pizzeria closed recently, leaving a gap in the dining scene.  Maxwell and Halford Drug, a quaint, family-owned pharmacy, is famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola. Independent Grocers Alliance (IGA), the town's sole grocery store, is a small but pricey affair. While it serves the community, many residents prefer the convenience of a larger Walmart in the neighboring town of Batesburg-Leesville. 

Dollar General, however, reigns supreme, bustling with activity from opening to closing. Possibilities Furniture & More, a beloved local business, offers a wide selection of furniture and even provides delivery.  Attached is Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a haven for furry friends with daycare, boarding, grooming, and more.

Johnston also boasts a well-equipped doctor's office and veterinary clinic, both tucked away from the main street.  Children attend Johnston Elementary School until fifth grade, after which they venture to the next town for middle and high school.

While Johnston lacks traditional parks, a new 2.5-acre recreational area is in the works, aiming to create more family-friendly spaces and attract new residents. Entertainment options are limited, with no movie theaters, bowling alleys, or playgrounds.  

Despite the lack of buzz, Johnston is a peaceful town, so small it could easily be missed. But its charm and close-knit community make it a special place.

I first heard about my neighborhood from a podcast about missing persons, which was a bit surprising. Rent for most apartments here is over a thousand dollars a month, and I'd never heard any stories about disappearances, nor had my friends. Perhaps it's the struggle that keeps things quiet. I know some friends who cry themselves to sleep at night because of the high cost of living.  We've learned to be resourceful over the years. We've come to appreciate the dusty charm of flea market finds and secondhand clothing.  You simply don't smell as much as an adult. Maybe you start smoking, or maybe you just become accustomed to the way things are. But the flea market always finds a way back into your life. The scent of adulthood is reminiscent of dusty magazines piled on a closed piano, clinging to the leather even after washing.  Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. Starting at one end, you can visit two charity shops, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is bustling with cars and people every morning, but you wouldn't hear a thing inside the thrift stores. Regardless of the crowds, the stores remain serene. It's a perfect place to lose an afternoon. Every year, the city seems to grow more crowded. Cars and people flood the streets. They call it a developing city, with one of the biggest online empires for e-commerce and delivery headquartered here. It still has growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone is focused on their own goals, and no one demands much from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people leave you be. It's not like the South, where a little concern is seen as caring. People here don't pry into each other's lives. You can hold onto your solitude as long as you want, and the city will ebb and flow like waves on the beach. It's a vibrant place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur singers upstairs, there's always something happening. In a way, we have less of an apartment building filled with strangers and more of a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and support each other whenever we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I make sure to clean up after myself and leave them food, and they do the same for me. I bring them their mail, and they bring mine. It's nice to see them, and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, impersonal modernist complex, but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I haven't completely messed up my life.

My neighborhood is pretty much what you'd expect from a typical suburban area.  There's a clear influence from the homeowner's association, which keeps everything looking neat and tidy.  Every house is a single-family home, all well-maintained and similar in style.  The front yards are all pretty much the same: a patch of grass, some decorative rocks, and a short driveway. You'll occasionally see a small tree here and there.  Every house has a two-car garage.

The roads are in great shape – newly paved concrete stretches throughout the entire neighborhood. It's really impressive considering we have so many families living here.  You won't find any potholes or anything like that. Most of the houses are single-story, but you'll also see a few two-story homes mixed in.

Now, the mailbox situation is a little different from what you usually see in suburban neighborhoods. Instead of individual mailboxes in front of each house, we have a shared mailbox cluster at the end of the street, similar to what you'd find in an apartment complex. Everyone uses a key to access their own mailbox, and there are also a couple of bigger lockers for packages.  It's all about that HOA uniformity, I guess.

Being on the edge of the city, our neighborhood has a mix of suburban and rural vibes. We have a lot of space, which is great. There are multiple community pools that everyone can use, they're well-maintained and gated. We also have walking trails where you can walk your dog or just take a leisurely stroll.

The majority of the community is made up of retirees, which gives the neighborhood a peaceful and safe atmosphere. Everyone looks out for each other.  You also see a mix of middle-aged and younger professionals sprinkled in.

The city itself is surprisingly large in terms of population, but still has a small-town feel.  We have most of the amenities you'd expect, like a single mall, which isn't huge but gets the job done. It takes about 15 minutes to drive to anything significant, but once you get there, there's a wide variety of stores to choose from – everything from upscale grocery stores with organic food to budget-friendly outlets with limited selections and minimal staff.


Overall, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty standard suburban fare. We have nice things like pools and trails, and although we're not right next to any big shopping centers, it's just a quick car ride to any major chain store you might need.

I call a small Midwestern town my home, nestled just beyond the sprawl of a bustling city. My neighborhood, on the east side, is considered one of the less affluent areas, with modest homes mostly occupied by those with limited means.  It's not an unattractive place, though. My neighbors are a friendly bunch, always ready with a wave and a hello. While crime rates are a bit higher here compared to other parts of town, they're still relatively low. Over the past decade, there have been a few disturbing incidents nearby, including shootings and even a homicide, a stark reminder of the challenges we face.  Last year, our neighbors across the street lost their son in a shooting outside a local bar, a tragedy that deeply impacted our community.  Thankfully, our family hasn't been directly affected by crime beyond the occasional missing item from our porch.

Our town, like many across the nation, has been grappling with the devastating opioid epidemic. The toll of fentanyl overdoses has been heartbreaking.  But amidst these struggles, there are glimmers of hope.  Our town has rallied, establishing addiction recovery centers and offering Narcan training to families and friends, providing support for those battling this crisis. 

Despite its challenges, our town holds many treasures. My son's elementary school is a shining example.  From the dedicated principal to the compassionate teachers and supportive staff, they create a truly nurturing environment.  My son, who has special needs, has thrived there, free from bullying, a testament to the school's positive atmosphere. Our active PTO organizes events throughout the year, fostering a strong sense of community and promoting academic growth. Recognizing the economic realities of our town, where over 20% of residents live below the poverty line, the school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring that no child goes hungry.  

The city council and staff have made noticeable efforts to enhance our town's appearance, repaving roads, landscaping, and revitalizing city parks.  However, these improvements have primarily focused on the downtown area and the west side, where most businesses and traffic are concentrated.  The east side, where I live, has been largely overlooked, a source of frustration for many of us.

Overall, I find myself content living here.  The people are kind, the schools are exceptional, and we have access to a good variety of shops, both small businesses and larger retailers, to meet our needs. Our home may not be a grand estate, but it's comfortable and meets our needs. We've called this town home for over 16 years, and it's hard to imagine ourselves anywhere else.

My neighborhood is a tapestry woven with history and culture. It sits gracefully upon a hill, cradled by buildings that whisper tales of times gone by. My home, a seven-story apartment building, stands proudly opposite a historic theater, its grandeur a constant reminder of the past. A short stroll down the hill leads to a charming arcade bar, a beacon of warmth and laughter that draws diverse crowds on balmy summer nights, especially in June and July, when lines snake around the block, eager to step inside. A few blocks further up the hill lies a city park, a haven of green amidst the urban sprawl. Surrounding it is a concrete wall, its steps a staircase to the sky. During the biting winter months, the park becomes a sanctuary for those without homes, their tents forming a poignant huddle along the sidewalk and the wide steps. Rain, a relentless force in mid-winter, turns the concrete into a slick, unforgiving surface. By sharing the warmth of their makeshift homes, they find solace in community, and the proximity to the city's only family center, where they can find respite and comfort, offers a lifeline.

But the true heart of my neighborhood lies not in its ancient walls or architectural splendor, though those are certainly captivating. It's the people, their resilience and spirit, that truly define Hilltop. Once shrouded in the shadow of gang violence, its streets bore witness to a dark chapter in the city's history. The echoes of those tumultuous times linger still, whispered tales passed down through generations, a stark reminder of the battles fought and won. Despite its reputation, the people of Hilltop work tirelessly to maintain its dignity, a testament to their unwavering pride.  They care deeply for their community, their bond forged in the fires of hardship.

The warning, often uttered to outsiders, "Don't walk around Hilltop after dark if you're white," carries the weight of history, a relic of a time when fear and prejudice reigned. Perhaps, in my own way, I blend in, a testament to the city's melting pot, or maybe Hilltop sees in me a kindred spirit, someone who understands the enduring scars of racism and social conditioning.

Whatever the reason, I know this – Hilltop is my home.  Here, on these streets, I feel a sense of belonging, a connection to a community that embraces me with open arms. I've been offered warmth and kindness, a gesture of humanity that transcends the boundaries of race and prejudice. From a stranger's jacket on a cold night to a laundromat owner patiently waiting to let me charge my phone, Hilltop has shown me the true meaning of compassion.

In the midst of a storm, a stranger's five dollars and a simple affirmation, "You're beautiful and valuable," have warmed my soul. Hilltop is a place where hearts connect, where differences fade, and where the spirit of humanity shines brightest.

I call Rural Michigan, specifically a small town in its heart, home. Here, rolling farmland seamlessly transitions into quaint tourist spots.  Forget bustling city centers, gleaming malls, or even familiar chains like Walmart or Applebee's - everything requires a drive. Yet, despite this simplicity, I live in one of the most breathtaking places imaginable, surrounded by shimmering water. My community, nestled between the grandeur of Lake Michigan and the charm of Lake Charlevoix, offers a beach practically around every corner.

My neighborhood embodies the essence of small-town living. Houses aren't crammed together, nor are they cookie-cutter replicas.  Instead, they are older, unique homes, some modernized, others retaining their vintage charm. Most boast full, visible basements, and the streets are lined with houses in every color imaginable, sporting aluminum siding that whispers of bygone eras. Yards are abundant, filled with the laughter of children on trampolines and playsets. Gardens bloom, fences enclose furry friends, and the air hums with the spirit of hard-working families.

Kids chase each other down sidewalks, dogs bound happily alongside their owners, and bikes and rollerblades weave between houses. Here, neighbors know each other, recognizing both the familiar faces and the newcomers.  A friendly wave over a backyard grill, a pleasant smile exchanged with a dog walker - these are the things that weave a sense of community. Lawns are meticulously maintained, free of fallen leaves, with well-manicured grass and neatly trimmed bushes. It's not a neighborhood that screams "look at these mansions!" but rather whispers, "this is a place where families thrive."

The peacefulness and safety of our town are palpable. Within walking distance, you'll find the sheriff's department and jail, ensuring a watchful eye. The health department stands nearby, a reminder of community well-being. The recycling center hums with activity, serving residents from across the town. Baseball games fill the air with the roar of the crowd, while the nearby airport echoes with the gentle hum of small planes taking off and landing. A short stroll takes you to a local ice cream parlor, and a longer walk leads to the heart of town.

My children can bike to the park, just eight blocks away, a testament to the walkability of our community. It's a truly wonderful place to call home.

original_texts:
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downward, and my house sits right at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "work out hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily work out. As there aren't any sidewalks at all on my street everyone walks on the road. There road is pitted in a few places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires strung up around the block at tattered looking. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often strike down the power lines and the constant repairs make them look checkered and patchwork-y. There's many tall evergreen trees all around everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees obstruct the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's gorgeous around sunset when the water seems to get lit up from below and the sky turns orange. It's cloudy more often than not, though, so you end up seeing most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off. There aren't that many children around where I live, though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting out in people's lawns or racing down the street after each other.
